abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Venezuela - Water and
            Sewerage Decentralization Project in the State of Monagas
            was unsatisfactory, the sustainability was unlikely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, the Bank
            performance was satisfactory and the borrower performance
            was unsatisfactory. The lessons learned indicated that the
            absence of coherent sector policies, a supportive legal
            framework, and an effective institutional structure makes it
            very difficult to implement a well-designed and fairly
            limited pilot project. Since private participation in water
            services is usually politically sensitive, it is important
            that it is associated explicitly with service improvements
            for the poor. In an environment of political turmoil in
            which government officials and staff changed frequently, the
            management contract provided some stability for the water
            services in Monagas and produced significant improvements in
            commercial/financial performance, and service. The failure
            of political authorities to support a tariff policy in
            secondary cities of Monagas, undermined the financial
            viability of Monagas Water and Sewerage. The project team
            and regional management made adequate concessions and
            provided an appropriate level of assistance to the
            government in light of the difficulties it was facing during implementation.
